title-group.article-title: Genetic and Environmental Contributions to Child Height in Low‐ and Middle‐Income Countries

aff.named-content: UniSA Allied Health and Human Performance
Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, School of Public Health

aff.institution: South Australian Health and Medical Research Institute

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). American Journal of Human Biology published by Wiley Periodicals LLC.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Child height is influenced by genetic and environmental factors. However, it is unclear how these factors vary by geographical region and by study design, particularly in low‐ and middle‐income countries (LMIC), where data is scarce. Understanding these variations will aid the identification of factors that may be hindering growth in specific populations.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We analyzed height data of children under 5 years of age from 17 066 twin pairs and 2 024 672 parent‐offspring pairs using the Demographic and Health Surveys conducted in 69 countries. We estimated genetic and environmental contributions to child height using a mixture distribution model for twins to account for unknown zygosity and a parent‐offspring regression for singletons. A mixture distribution model assumes that the sample comprises a mixture of monozygotic and dizygotic twins and estimates heritability based on the distribution of phenotypic similarity across twin pairs, without requiring prior classification of zygosity.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Twin studies consistently estimated heritability at 0.35 (95% CI, 0.34–0.37) across all regions. The estimated proportion of phenotypic variance attributable to shared environmental factors was 0.63 (95% CI, 0.62–0.63), while the contribution of unique environmental factors was 0.02 (95% CI, 0.02–0.02). Conversely, there was variation in the heritability estimates from parent‐offspring studies, ranging from 0.27 (95% CI, 0.26–0.30) in North Africa, West Asia and Europe to 0.47 (95% CI, 0.46–0.48) in Latin America and Caribbean.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The observed discrepancies between twin and family study estimates underscore the complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. These variations suggest that environmental factors play a critical role in determining height outcomes during childhood. Further research is needed to explore these environmental factors in greater detail with the aim of developing region‐specific interventions to address height disparities, particularly in underprivileged regions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Stunting, affecting 29% of children globally (Ssentongo et al. 2021), is a critical public health concern with significant long‐term consequences for individual and societal well‐being. It is associated with increased risks of chronic diseases, such as hypertension, obesity, and diabetes in adulthood, as well as adverse maternal and reproductive outcomes (De Sanctis et al. 2021; Dewey and Begum 2011; Muhammad 2018). A child is categorized as stunted when their height falls more than two standard deviations (SDs) below their expected height from the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards median (WHO 2014). Thus, child height is an important measure for evaluating their growth and determining stunting.

While both genetic and environmental factors significantly influence child height (Dewau et al. 2024; Jelenkovic et al. 2016, 2020; Sarma 2009; Silventoinen et al. 2008), it is crucial to understand their relative contributions in different populations. This knowledge can be useful for developing effective interventions to address stunting, as it helps distinguish between genetically determined variations in height and those resulting from environmental factors, such as malnutrition and poor living conditions (Raiten and Bremer 2020).

Despite growing recognition of regional and socioeconomic influences on the heritability of height, there remains a significant gap in our understanding of how genetic and environmental contributions to height vary across low‐ and middle‐income countries. Previous research has demonstrated substantial variation in heritability estimates, ranging from 20% to 30% in China to as high as 97% in European populations (Liu et al. 2015; Lunde et al. 2007; Mook‐Kanamori et al. 2012; Silventoinen et al. 2007, 2008). These findings underscore the importance of contextual factors, such as nutrition, health care access, and social inequalities in moderating genetic influences on growth (Steckel 2009).

A recent systematic review highlighted the scarcity of genetic research on child growth in LMIC, where most existing studies focused on European ancestries and high‐income settings (Dewau et al. 2024). This limits the generalizability of findings and overlooks the variability in genetic and environmental influences across diverse socio‐demographic contexts. For example, although heritability estimates derived from the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) twin data in LMIC have been reported (Karlsson et al. 2022), these estimates are not region‐specific, limiting their utility for understanding local patterns of genetic and environmental contributions.

Furthermore, a recent work by (Bogin 2021) emphasizes the complex interplay between ecological stressors and biological plasticity, which likely modulates the expression of genetic potential in under‐resourced settings. Yet, few studies have systematically examined these dynamics using representative datasets from LMIC.

Traditionally, twin studies estimate heritability by comparing how similar identical (monozygotic [MZ]) compared to fraternal (dizygotic [DZ]) twins. However, zygosity information is often unavailable in low‐resource settings. To address this, researchers have applied the mixture distribution model, which estimates heritability by assuming that same‐sex (SS) twin pairs have equal probabilities of being MZ or DZ, and that opposite‐sex pairs are DZ (Neale 2003). This approach has been successfully used in studies of cognitive trait (Benyamin et al. 2006, 2005; Neale 2003), child height (Karlsson et al. 2022) and health outcomes using insurance data (Lakhani et al. 2019).

In this study we leverage the extensive DHS database (DHS 2022), and apply both twin and parent‐offspring designs (Falconer 1996) to estimate the genetic and environmental contributions to child height across different developing regions to capture contextual variability. Our findings provide valuable insights for public health efforts by disentangling the genetic and environmental contributions to childhood height, informing region‐specific targeted interventions to improve child growth and development in LMIC.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: The DHS program, conducted in 90 countries worldwide, collects comprehensive data on population, health, and nutrition (DHS 2022), offering a unique opportunity to investigate the determinants of child growth on a global scale. Within DHS, these countries are classified into 6 geographic regions: Southeast Asia; Central Asia; Sub‐Saharan Africa (SSA); North Africa, West Asia, and Europe (NAWAE); Oceania; and Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). For this study, we combined Southeast Asia and Central Asia (Asia) and excluded Oceania due to a small sample size. The list of countries and the corresponding sample size in each region is provided in Table S1. Country‐specific analyses were only conducted in the parent‐offspring design as the sample size in twin design are too small. Participants included women aged 15–49 years, men aged 15–59 years, and their children from randomly selected households within each country. Detailed health and birth histories were collected for all participants. Anthropometric measurements, including height and weight, were recorded for both parents and children. Child height was measured using a standardized protocol, including recumbent length for infants and standing height for older children, with a theoretical accuracy of 0.1 cm (ICF 2020). The dataset includes information on child age (in months), sex, and birth type. Extreme height values were excluded based on biological plausibility criteria to reduce measurement error. Specifically, we excluded children with recorded heights of < 40 cm or > 60 cm at birth, < 50 cm in children older than 1 year, and > 120 cm in children younger than 5 years. These cut‐offs were informed by typical growth ranges observed in early childhood (Q. P. Endocriniology 2021; WHO 2006).

sec.title: Stunting Prevalence, Mean Height, and Growth Velocity
sec.p: To estimate the prevalence of stunting in DHS data, we followed the 2006 WHO Child Growth Standards, where children were classified as stunted if their height‐for‐age measurements fell more than two SDs below the median (WHO 2014). The prevalence of stunting was calculated as the proportion of stunted children to the total number of children measured. Sampling weight was applied to account for the unequal probability sampling in DHS sample selection (ICF International 2012). Mean height was calculated height in centimeters (cm) at each year, below and above 2 years and in all children under 5 years of age, with a mean age of 28 months for both singletons and twins. Height difference in twins was compared using square difference in height as a function of age. Growth velocity (GV) was calculated by taking the difference between mean height measurements at two consecutive ages and dividing by the time interval (in years) between those ages. Specifically, the GV in centimeters per year was computed as the change in mean height over the age interval. To estimate the confidence interval (CI) for GV, we used the propagation of error method assuming independence of the two means. The standard error of the GV was calculated by combining the standard errors of the mean heights at each age, divided by the length of the age interval (Cohen 1998). The 95% CI was then derived by multiplying the standard error by 1.96 and adding and subtracting this value from the GV estimate. This method provided a measure of the precision around the estimated average GV over each age interval.

GV was calculated as follows:(1)GV=H2−H1∆tStandard error of growth velocity (seGV)(2)seGV=se12+se22∆t (3)95%CIforGV:CI=GV±1.96×seGVwhere: H 1 = mean height at earlier age, H 2 = mean height at later age, se1 = standard error of mean height at earlier age, se2 = standard error of mean height at later age, ∆t = time interval in years between the two ages.

sec.title: Estimation of Genetic and Environmental Contributions
sec.p: We estimated the relative contributions of genetic and environmental factors on the variation in child height by employing twin study and mother‐offspring designs. The analyses were stratified by DHS geographic regions, age group, and sex (for parent‐offspring design only). Sex stratification was not possible in the twin design due to the requirement of both sexes for the analysis of twins with unknown zygosity. While DHS datasets were classified into six geographic regions, our study focused only on four regions (Asia, SSA, NAWAE, and LAC) where adequate sample sizes are available. Height was analyzed at different ages: infants (0–2 years old) and preschool children (2–4 years old). To investigate the trend of heritability, we also analyzed height at birth to less than a month, the first 6 months (1 –6 months), the first year (6–18 months), the second year (19–30 months), the third year (30–42 months), and the fourth year (42–59 months).

sec.title: Twin Design Analysis
sec.p: In the classical twin design, the phenotypic variance of a trait can be partitioned into additive genetic variance (A), common (or shared) environmental factors (C), and specific (or nonshared) environmental factors, which include measurement error (E). This model is known as an ACE model (Arbet et al. 2020; Neale and Cardon 1992).

Let assume a study involving N = N MZ + N DZ twin pairs. If yz=yz1yz2T represents a quantitative outcome measured on a pair of twins (twin 1 and twin 2), where z being either MZ or DZ and xzT is a 2 × P matrix of P covariates for both twins, the twin ACE model is then defined as:(4)yZ=xTzβ+AZ+CZ+EZWhere E(y
z ) = x Tzβ and cov(yz) = cov(Az) + cov(Cz) + cov(Ez).

The mean and covariance structures for the ACE random effects are defined as follows:(5)AZ~0σ2AZKZ (6)CZ~0σ2CZJZ (7)EZ~0σ2EZIzwhere I is a two by two identity matrix, J is a two by two matrix of ones and K
z = 1wzwz1 is the genetic relationship matrix. Note that w
z = 1 for identical or MZ twins and w
z = 0.5 for non‐identical or DZ twins. Where variance components σ 2 A
z = additive genetic, σ 2 C
z = common environment, and σ 2 E
z = unique environment for twin type z, then the heritability (h 2) is estimated as:(8)h2=σ2Azσ2Az+σ2Cz+σ2Ez (9)c2=σ2Czσ2Az+σ2Cz+σ2Ez (10)e2=1−h2+c2As we can see from the equation, the classical twin design requires the information on the zygosity of the twins, that is, MZ or DZ. The zygosity is unknown in the DHS twin data, so we applied a mixture distribution model (Neale 2003) to estimate the genetic and environmental contributions to childhood height. This method assumes that the sample comprises a mixture of MZ and DZ twins and estimates heritability based on the distribution of trait similarity across twin pairs, without requiring prior classification of zygosity. This method effectively mitigates potential biases that could arise from arbitrary assignment or exclusion of twins with unknown zygosity, which might otherwise lead to under‐ or overestimation of heritability, and detailed statistical analysis is explained as follows.

Our analysis utilized a mixture distribution approach to account for twin zygosity, a method distinct from the direct MZ/DZ classification used in classical twin designs. In this framework, twin pairs were categorized based on sex: SS or different‐sex (DS). All DS twin pairs are dizygotic (DZDS). Conversely, SS twin pairs comprise an unobserved mixture of monozygotic (MZSS) and dizygotic (DZSS) individuals.

A key assumption in this model is that the genetic and environmental correlations for DZDS pairs are equal to those for DZSS pairs. The observed phenotypic correlation for SS pairs was then modeled as a weighted average, or mixture, of the underlying correlations for MZSS and DZSS pairs. Using a maximum likelihood estimation procedure, the contribution of each SS twin pair to the overall likelihood was weighted by its probability of being MZ or DZ. The initial p(MZ), representing the probability of a SS pair being MZ, was determined using Weinberg's differential rule: 1–2 × P(DS) (Lakhani et al. 2019; Weinberg 1901). To assess the robustness of our findings, we performed sensitivity analyses by varying the p(MZ) input for heritability estimates of childhood height. As these estimates remained stable across different p(MZ) scenarios (Figure Table S1), a fixed p(MZ) of 0.5 was adopted for all subsequent analyses. This method effectively mitigates potential biases that could arise from arbitrary assignment or exclusion of twins with unknown zygosity, which might otherwise lead to under‐ or overestimation of heritability (Benyamin et al. 2005; Neale and Cardon 1992; Neale 2003). The CIs for the heritability estimates were calculated using bootstrap resampling of the twin pairs. Specifically, we generated 1000 bootstrap replicates by randomly sampling, with replacement, from the original dataset of twin pairs. In each replicate, the number of sampled pairs equaled the number of non‐missing observations in the original dataset. We then used the distribution of these bootstrap estimates to construct 95% CIs. All analyses were conducted using R version 4.4.0. Following Karlsson et al. (2022) (Karlsson et al. 2022), we adjusted the height for the effects of age and sex using a two‐step process. Firstly, we adjusted the height of children for their age. Since children's heights are measured cross‐sectionally at various ages (birth to 59 months), there may be differences in height purely due to age, regardless of other factors. To account for this, we used a LOESS regression, which is a flexible nonparametric method for fitting curves to data. This captures any nonlinear relationship between height and age. By doing this, we can remove the age‐related variation in height, leaving behind the residuals, which represent the difference between the observed height and the height predicted by the LOESS curve for a given age. Secondly, after obtaining the residuals for each child (which represent the difference between their actual height and the height predicted by the LOESS curve for their age), we further adjust these residuals for sex‐related differences. This ensures that any variation in height between males and females is accounted for, allowing for a more accurate analysis of height differences that are not related to sex. To capture the growing variability in height by age, we determine a projected SD of height based on a LOESS model as a function of age. Finally, the residualized values obtained from the first step are standardized using the fitted values from the second step. This step ensures that the adjusted heights are on a consistent scale, making them comparable across different ages and sexes. Then, we used the residuals in the mixed distribution model to estimate the variance components.

sec.title: Parent‐Offspring Design Analysis
sec.p: Twin studies provide valuable insights into the relative importance of genetic contribution, while parent‐offspring analyses offer complementary information on the transmission of both genetic and environmental influences across generations (Jami et al. 2021). In addition to twin design, parent‐offspring design can also be used to quantify the relative contribution of genetic and environmental factors within a population (Balbona et al. 2022). To estimate the heritability of child height using the parent‐offspring design, we conducted a linear regression analysis in which the child's height was regressed on the mother's height, household wealth, maternal education, child sex, and age. The slope of the regression line represents the degree of resemblance between mothers and their children. Under the assumption of additive genetic inheritance, the heritability estimate (h 2) and its CI were obtained by doubling the regression coefficient and its CI (h 2 = 2 × β). This method assumes no assortative mating, shared environment effects are minimal, and that the parent‐offspring resemblance reflects additive genetic contributions (Kempthorne and Tandon 1953). Due to the lack of paternal height data, only mother‐offspring pairs were used in this analysis.

sec.title: Covariate Adjustment
sec.p: To account for the influence of known environmental factors on child height, we included the following covariates in the mother‐offspring regression models: child's age (in months), maternal education level (categorical: no education, primary, secondary, and higher), household wealth index (categorical: poorest, poorer, middle, richer, and richest). The household wealth index in the DHS data is a composite measure derived using principal component analysis (PCA) on household asset data (Rutstein and Johnson 2004). This approach considers various factors, such as housing materials, water access, sanitation facilities, and ownership of durable goods (e.g., televisions and bicycles). Households are then ranked and categorized into quintiles (from poorest to richest) based on their wealth scores. This standardized index facilitates comparisons of socioeconomic status across households and regions within the study (Rutstein and Johnson 2004).

sec.title: Heritability Estimation
sec.p:
We adjusted for unequal height variances between males and females to avoid biased heritability estimates from sex‐pooled regression analyses. Specifically, we applied sex‐stratified regression and scaled each regression coefficient by multiplying it by its corresponding sex‐specific variance ratio. For males, the coefficient was multiplied by the male‐to‐female variance ratio; for females, by the female‐to‐male ratio. This standardization ensures that differences in phenotypic variance between sexes do not distort the heritability estimate. Finally, heritability was calculated by doubling the adjusted regression coefficient and its standard error (Falconer 1989, 1996).(11)Sons'height=βs*mother height+e (12)Daughters'height=βd*mother height+e (13)Sons'h2=2*σ2sσ2d×βs (14)Daughters'h2=2*σ2dσ2s×βdwhere h 2 = heritability, σ 2
S and σ 2
d = phenotypic variance of sons and daughters, respectively. β
s and β
d = regression coefficients for sons and daughters, respectively, and e = residual error.

sec.title: Testing for Differences
sec.p: Mean height differences by region and age were assessed using one‐way ANOVA, with Bonferroni‐adjusted post hoc comparisons to account for multiple testing. Results were stratified by child age and region, and no interaction terms were included. To compare the prevalences of stunting across sex and geographic regions, we used Chi‐square tests. Statistical significance was defined as p < 0.05.

sec.title: Ethical Consideration
sec.p: While ethical oversight typically rests with the institutions conducting surveys, the authors of this research obtained written permission from the MEASURE DHS Program to utilize the dataset. This written approval letter authorized the use of the data. Before data collection, all DHS data collection materials underwent review and approval for compliance with the 45 CFR 46 regulations (“Protection of Human Subjects”) by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of each participating country. Confidentiality was maintained through anonymization, and the data was used exclusively for the purposes of this study. Furthermore, the Human Research Ethics Committee (HREC) of the University of South Australia (UniSA) has reviewed the study and determined that it is exempt from requiring ethics approval under application number 204925.

sec.title: Study Sample Characteristics
sec.p: Initially, data from 39 340 twin pairs and 2 849 133 singletons children were extracted from 267 DHSs conducted across 69 countries (Table 1). We then excluded data from 20 145 twin pairs and 824 461 singletons that have no height measurements. We also excluded 2165 twin and 43 498 child–mother pairs where the children's height is extreme child height values (See the method section). After exclusions, the final dataset included 17 066 twin pairs [10 770 (63%) SS and 6296 (37%) DS pairs] and 2 024 672 mother–child pairs (Figure 1). Sub‐Saharan Africa (SSA) represents the highest proportion of twin pairs (54%), followed by Asia (22%) and LAC and NAWAE (both at 12%). The proportion of SS twin pairs varied across regions, ranging from 60% in SSA to 68% in Asia and LAC. For singletons, 932 577 (46%) and 689 906 (34%) of children originate from SSA and Asia, respectively (Table 1). The number of individuals stratified by individual countries is presented in Table S1.

caption.p: The number of children from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data by geographic region, age, sex and birth type (1986 to 2021) used in this study.

fn.p: Abbreviations: Asia, Central and Southwest Asia; LAC, Latin America and Caribbean; NAWAE, North Africa, West Asia, and Europe; SSA, Sub‐Saharan Africa.

caption.p: Data extraction flow diagram from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) for childhood heritability estimation using twin and parent–offspring designs. The flow illustrates the identification and selection of eligible twin pairs and child–mother pairs across multiple surveys. Twin pairs were categorized as same‐sex (SS) or different‐sex (DS) for subsequent heritability analyses. n indicates the number of twin pairs or child–mother pairs included at each stage.

sec.title: Socio‐Economic Factors
sec.p: Wealth distribution is broadly similar across regions, with 47%–54% in lower and 25%–33% in higher wealth quintiles. In contrast, maternal education shows greater variation: SSA has the highest proportion of mothers with low education (81%), while NAWAE and Asia have more balanced levels, and LAC shows moderate attainment (41% with secondary or higher education) (Table S2).

sec.title: Prevalence of Stunting
sec.p: Stunting prevalences varied significantly by birth type (p value < 0.001), sex (p value < 0.01), and geographic region (p value < 0.001). The overall prevalence of stunting across all regions was higher in twins (47%) than in singletons (35%) and in males (36%) compared to females (33%). Stunting was most prevalent in SSA (48%) and Asia (38%) and least prevalent in NAWAE (29%) and LAC (24%) for both twins and singletons (Table 2). We also observed variations in stunting prevalence between singletons and twins within each region (p values < 0.001), but not between first‐born and second‐born twins. The prevalences of stunting stratified by region, age, sex, and birth type are presented in Table S3.

caption.p: Prevalence of stunting in under 5 years across geographic regions, birth type and sex in DHS data (1986–2021).

fn.p: Abbreviations: Asia, Central and Southwest Asia; LAC, Latin America and Caribbean; NAWAE, North Africa, West Asia, and Europe; SSA, Sub‐Saharan Africa.

sec.title: Mean Height of Twins in Four DHS Regions
sec.p: Mean height (in cm) of twins across different age categories (from birth to 4 years) by regions presented (Table S4). At birth, the mean height is lowest in LAC and similar across the three regions. After 6 months, children in SSA demonstrate notably the lowest height compared to the other regions. This trend continues at three and 4 years, where children in the SSA region consistently show the lowest mean height, whereas children in LAC and NAWAE regions tend to have slightly higher values as indicated by the nonoverlapping CIs (Figure S2).

Mean child height at each age category varied significantly between geographic regions for both twins and singletons (p‐value < 0.001), except for twins between Asia and Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). For all children with a mean age of 28 months, the lowest mean heights were recorded in SSA at 78.85 ± 14.61 cm and 81.28 ± 14.07 cm, and the highest in NAWEA at 84.18 ± 14.85 cm and 85.05 ± 14.86 cm for twins and singletons, respectively (Tables S4 and S8b). Across regions, twins were shorter than singletons before the age of 2 years, with no significant differences observed at older ages, except in the LAC region (Tables S4–S6 and S8a,b). No significant height differences were found between first‐born and second‐born twins or between SS and DS twins (Table S4).

GV peaks at the age of 1 year across all regions, with the highest mean values observed in LAC (24.43: 95% CI, 22.67–26.19 cm/year) in males, and (22.26: 95% CI, 20.85–23.67 cm/year) in females, followed by NAWAE and Asia. Sub‐Saharan Africa shows slightly lower values at peak but maintains relatively stable growth rates beyond infancy compared to Asia. Males consistently exhibit higher growth velocities than females. The observed decline in GV after the age of 1 year aligns with the expected child growth trajectories, although the lower velocities in Asia may suggest early growth faltering. CIs suggest higher precision in estimates where sample sizes are large, especially between ages 1 and 4 (Table S5 and Figure S3).
Maternal height varied across regions, with SSA recording the tallest average maternal height at (158.43 ± 6.6 cm) and Asian ancestry populations displaying the shortest (151.7 ± 5.6 cm) (Table S5).

Children of mothers with a lower educational level and with the poorest household wealth index grew slower compared to those of mothers with higher education and from wealthier households (Figure S4). After adjusting for maternal height, child sex, and age, both household wealth and maternal education were positively associated with child height across all regions. Children from wealthier households showed higher mean height compared to those from the poorest households, with a consistent gradient observed across quintiles. For example, in Asia, children from the richest households had height 1.5 cm higher than those from the poorest households (β = 1.5, SE = 0.032, p < 0.001). Similarly, maternal education showed a dose–response relationship with child height. Compared to children of mothers with no education, those whose mothers were educated beyond high school were, on average, 2.2 cm taller in Asia (SE = 0.04) and 2.8 cm taller in SSA (SE = 0.07, p < 0.001). The patterns were consistent, but the magnitudes varied slightly across regions (Table S2).

The correlation between the first‐ and second‐born twins' height was high and similar across all regions, measuring at 0.98. Within SS twin pairs, the correlation coefficient was 0.98, while in DS pairs, it was at 0.97 (Table S7). On average, the mean height difference between first‐ and second‐born twins was 0.35 cm. This difference was slightly higher in DS (0.45 cm) compared to SS (0.30 cm) twin pairs.

The squared difference in height between twin pairs provides a valuable measure of their height similarity, which is crucial for estimating heritability. Smaller squared differences indicate greater height similarity. As expected, the squared height differences were generally smaller in SS twin pairs, which include both MZ and DZ twins, compared to DS, which are entirely DZ twin pairs (Figure S5). This observation aligns with the expectation that, on average, SS twins, particularly MZ twins, tend to demonstrate greater height similarity than DS twins.

sec.title: Heritability Estimates From Twin Design
sec.p: The estimated heritability (h 2) of height in children under 5 years old was 0.35 (95% CI, 0.34–0.37). This estimate remained relatively consistent across geographical regions, with the lowest value (0.33, 95% CI, 0.30–0.36) observed in Asia and the highest (0.35, 95% CI, 0.30–0.40) in North Africa and Western Asia (NAWAE). No significant differences in heritability estimates were found among regions for children under 2 years of age. A modest increase in heritability was observed from birth (0.22; 95% CI, 0.14–0.36) to 4 years of age (0.29; 95% CI, 0.27–0.31) (Table 3).

caption.p: The proportion of phenotypic variance in childhood (0–5 years) height explained by genetic (h 2), shared (c 2) and unique (e 2) environmental factors by geographic regions estimated from twin design.

fn.p: Abbreviations: Asia, Central and Southwest Asia; DHS, Demographic and Health Survey; LAC, Latin America and Caribbean; NAWAE, North Africa, West Asia, and Europe; SSA, Sub‐Saharan Africa.

sec.p: The estimated proportion of phenotypic variance attributable to shared environmental factors (c 2) was 0.63 (95% CI, 0.62–0.63), while the contribution of unique environmental factors (e 2) was 0.02 (95% CI, 0.02–0.02) (Table 3).

sec.title: Heritability Estimates From Parent‐Offspring Design
sec.p: The heritability estimates derived from parent‐offspring based analyses varied across regions and increased with age. The variation in heritability estimates across regions may be linked to differences in the upbringing environments of parents and children. For example, the recent stable economic growth in NAWAE contrasts with the less sustainable growth in LAC, which may lead to more similar environments between parents and children in LAC. This environmental similarity could result in stronger mother‐to‐child height correlations in LAC compared to the more varied environments in NAWAE, where the correlation may be weaker. Across regions, the heritability estimate increased from 0.16 (95% CI, 0.13–0.20) at birth in Asia to 0.61 (95% CI: 0.59–0.62) at the age of 4 years in LAC (Figure 2 and Table S9). Further, heritability estimates stratified by country showed some variation across countries and ages at measurement. However, the overlapping CIs suggest these differences should be interpreted with caution, and heritability estimates are generally comparable across regions. However, the trend that we observed in country‐specific analysis is similar to that of region‐based analysis, that is, the heritability increases as the children age (Data S2).

caption.p: Trends in heritability of height among children under 5 years of age, by age group and geographic region, based on the parent–offspring study design. The bars represent heritability estimates, and the error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals. Regions include: All, all ancestries combined; Asia, Central and Southwest Asia; LAC, Latin America and the Caribbean; NAWAE, North Africa, West Asia, and Europe; and SSA, Sub‐Saharan Africa.

sec.p: The estimates were highest in children from the LAC region ranging from 0.20 (95% CI: 0.14–0.26) at birth and reaching 0.61 (95% CI: 0.59–0.62) at 4 years of age. When we combined all data (i.e., not stratified by age), the estimated heritability was highest in LAC (0.47, 95% CI: 0.46–0.48) and the lowest in NAWAE (0.26, 95% CI: 0.26–0.29) (Figure 3 and Table S10).

caption.p: Heritability estimates of height in children aged 0–5 years across geographic regions, based on the parent–offspring study design. The bars represent heritability estimates, and the error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals for each region. Regional classifications: Asia, Central and Southwest Asia; LAC, Latin America and the Caribbean; NAWAE, North Africa, West Asia, and Europe; SSA Sub‐Saharan Africa.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we have investigated the relative contributions of genetic (heritability) and environmental factors influencing child height in LMIC. Specifically, we investigated whether these contributions vary across different geographic regions, ages, and study designs. As part of the broader context in understanding the relationship between child height and stunting, we also estimated the prevalence of stunting across different geographic regions and birth types. Although the prevalence of stunting varies across regions, heritability estimates from twin studies remained constant, while estimates from parent‐offspring studies showed regional differences.

The overall prevalence of stunting was higher in twins (47%) compared to singletons (35%), consistent with previous findings (Alemu et al. 2023; Choudhary et al. 2023). This difference in stunting prevalence between singletons and twins is mainly associated with preterm birth, competition for resources in utero, and intrauterine growth restrictions in twins (Luke et al. 1995). Notably, stunting prevalence was higher in male children compared to female children in both twins and singletons, potentially due to higher metabolic rates and increased susceptibility to infections in males (Thurstans et al. 2022).

Despite higher stunting rates in twins, they exhibited faster GV compared to singletons, leading to catch‐up growth in early childhood. This observation aligns with previous research (Estourgie‐van Burk et al. 2010) demonstrating that twins, although initially smaller, tend to reach comparable final heights to their siblings and the general population (Luke et al. 1995; Lundgren et al. 2001; Womack et al. 2023).

Regional differences in child height reflect the complex interplay of genetic and environmental factors, with NAWAE children being the tallest and SSA children the shortest. While LAC children had the shortest birth lengths, SSA children exhibited the lowest heights by ages one and two. The shorter birth lengths in LAC may stem from prenatal growth restrictions related to maternal stature and health (Sacker and Kelly 2012), whereas the postnatal growth decline in SSA likely results from chronic undernutrition, infections, and limited healthcare (Akombi et al. 2017; Danaei et al. 2016). In contrast, in favorable environments like the UK, children of African ancestry tend to be taller than their European peers, while South Asian and East Asian children are shorter, underscoring the interaction between genetics and environment in shaping growth (Lu et al. 2017; Sacker and Kelly 2012).

Our analysis of same‐ and different‐sex twin pairs revealed greater height variability in DS twins, aligning with findings from CODATwins (A. Jelenkovic et al. 2018). This is expected, as all DS twins are DZ, sharing only 50% genetic similarity, whereas SS twins include both MZ and DZ pairs, with MZ twins sharing 100% of their genome (Neale 2003). Gestational age differences may also play a role, as male co‐twins typically have shorter gestations (Lu et al. 2017), and males in DS pairs tend to be taller and heavier than their female co‐twin or SS male counterparts (Jahanfar and Lim 2016; Jelenkovic et al. 2018). These findings highlight the importance of gestational factors in twin studies and emphasize the need for further research into sex‐specific genetic and environmental influences on height variation.

Our analyses showed that the heritability estimates from twin design was about 35% in children 0 to 5 years, consistent with previous research (Dubois et al. 2012; Mook‐Kanamori et al. 2012; Silventoinen et al. 2008). These heritability estimates from twin designs did not significantly differ among the four geographic regions. Despite variations in socioeconomic and environmental conditions across different geographic regions in LMIC, our analysis found that heritability estimates for height remained relatively constant. This suggests that while environmental factors differ between regions, the overall level of environmental constraint on growth may still be substantial in all developing settings, as evidenced by high prevalence of stunting of 50% in twins, limiting genetic expression in a similar way.

Importantly, heritability reflects the proportion of variance due to genetic factors within a given environment rather than an absolute genetic influence on height. When environmental adversity is both significant and widespread, as in many developing regions, the relative contribution of genetic factors may appear stable (Jelenkovic et al. 2020). Our interpretation that heritability estimates may be lower in populations with greater environmental adversity (e.g., high stunting rates) follows the classical model of heritability, where increased environmental adversity reduces the relative impact of genetic differences. However, recent evidence challenges some of these assumptions. For instance, studies have shown that stunted populations are not always malnourished (Scheffler et al. 2020), and the phenotypic variance in height may remain comparable to that observed in high‐income settings (Christiane Scheffler and Hermanussen 2022). These findings suggest that the statistical estimation of heritability may remain stable across diverse environments, even when living conditions differ substantially. Thus, while our findings suggest some variability in heritability estimates across populations, these should be interpreted cautiously, acknowledging the complex and multifactorial nature of child growth.

Additionally, the lack of strong regional differences in heritability estimates could also result from limitations in sample size and measurement precision, which may obscure more subtle variations. Future research incorporating more detailed environmental data and alternative heritability estimation methods could help clarify these patterns. Notably, our estimates were lower than previous heritability estimates derived from DHS data (Karlsson et al. 2022). This discrepancy may be attributed to the difference in the exclusion of children outside plausible height limits for a given age and an increased sample size of twin pairs in our study.

Our estimates were consistently lower than those reported in several twin studies conducted in European countries after 1 year (Dubois et al. 2012; Jelenkovic et al. 2016; Mook‐Kanamori et al. 2012; Silventoinen et al. 2008). The estimates were also lower than the pooled estimates from the CODATwins project for the first 4 years (Jelenkovic et al. 2016) and the meta‐analysis of childhood heritability (Dewau et al. 2024). These lower estimates might be due to the difference in methods used, where twins with unknown zygosity were used in this study. The difference might also be due to higher environmental variations in LMIC. While participants in the CODATwins project predominantly were from Western populations characterized by nurturing and stable environments, our study participants predominantly grew up in areas facing nutritional and health challenges, potentially limiting growth potential. This discrepancy may also be associated with genetic differences among populations. Overall, these findings highlight the complex interaction between genetic and environmental factors in shaping child height across different populations and age groups.

Heritability estimates from mother‐offspring design varied considerably across regions, with the highest estimates observed in NAWAE and the lowest in Asia at birth. This regional variation was also observed within different European countries such as in the Netherlands (Mook‐Kanamori et al. 2012), Finland (Tiisala and Kantero 1971) and Norway (Lunde et al. 2007). After the age of 2 years, heritability is significantly higher in Asia and LAC regions compared to NAWAE. These subsequent shifts to higher heritability in Asia and LAC after 2 years of age compared to NAWAE suggest a complex interplay between genetic and environmental influences on child height. Furthermore, the observed variation in heritability across regions could be attributed to lower environmental correlation as a result of differences in environmental conditions experienced by mothers and offspring, likely influenced by remarkable economic stimulations, potentially driven by the oil economy and sustainable growth strategies in NAWAE compared to unstable economic growth in other regions. These economic changes may have significantly improved the children's environments compared to those of their parents. The discovery of oil markedly improves local production and generates positive spillover effects. This leads to a transition for workers shifting from informal, low‐productivity agriculture to higher value‐added activities in formal services, contributing to increased urbanization (Cavalcanti et al. 2019). This economic shift and corresponding increase in maternal awareness potentially improve child feeding and care practices at a level better than what was experienced during their upbringing. Overall improvements in a child's growing environment also play a significant role in enhancing psychosocial stimulation for growth (Bogin 2021). Therefore, the level of similarity might be lower than in the case in which both parents and children experienced the same condition (Tanner et al. 1970), which in turn reduces child to parent correlation and heritability (Mueller 1976).

The proportion of phenotypic variance attributed to the common environmental effects was high (62% in all regions). This is different from what is reported in the Western countries, where genetic factors contribute more to the variation in childhood height (Jelenkovic et al. 2016; Silventoinen et al. 2015). The lower heritability estimates we observed in the LMIC can be attributed to the higher environmental differences in these regions, as most of the twins were from SSA and Asia compared to more environmentally stable Western countries, particularly in nutrition and healthcare services during prenatal and early childhood. This is in line with the hypothesis that populations with greater access to nutrition and healthcare typically demonstrate higher heritability estimates of height as a result of less environmental variance (Silventoinen et al. 2003).

Unique environmental factors contributed minimally to the variation in child height in the DHS data. These factors typically include child‐specific experiences such as differential exposure to disease, malnutrition, or measurement errors. The estimate observed in our analysis was lower than that reported in the CODATwins study (Jelenkovic et al. 2016). One possible explanation for this discrepancy is that in LMIC, children are more likely to share similar living conditions and environmental exposures due to limited socioeconomic variation within households. These shared exposures such as poor nutrition, unsanitary conditions, and limited access to healthcare can inflate the common environmental (C) component, potentially masking the contribution of unique environmental (E) influences. As a result, the E component may appear lower or even undetectable in such contexts. Additionally, the lower E estimate might also be partly influenced by the use of an inferred twin zygosity classification method in the current study (Neale 2003), which could introduce some bias in partitioning variance components.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: This study has several strengths. Firstly, a key strength of our methodology is the application of a mixture distribution approach to account for zygosity uncertainty, thereby enhancing the robustness and validity of our heritability estimates. Secondly, it utilized both twin and mother‐offspring designs to investigate the interplay between genetic and environmental factors in shaping child growth across diverse populations. Thirdly, the use of the DHS database provided access to a large and geographically diverse dataset. Fourthly, the study accounted for key environmental factors, such as maternal education and household wealth, in the analyses.

However, several limitations should be acknowledged. The reliance on inferred zygosity in the twin analysis may introduce some uncertainty into the heritability estimates. The cross‐sectional nature of the data limits the ability to draw conclusions about the temporal dynamics of genetic and environmental influences on growth. Potential sources of measurement error, such as inaccuracies in height measurement in low‐resource settings, maternal recall of children's ages, and the limitations of socio‐economic indicators such as wealth may have introduced noise into the data and should be considered when interpreting the precision and reliability of the heritability estimates. Furthermore, the absence of paternal height data limits the ability to separate genetic contributions from maternal‐specific influences. Maternal height may reflect both inherited genetic factors and environmental influences, particularly in early childhood, when children are more dependent on the maternal environment. This overlap may result in gene–environment or environmental correlations that could inflate the apparent maternal effect and complicate the interpretation of heritability estimates (Falconer 1996).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study provides valuable insights into the complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors influencing child height variation in LMIC. Our findings highlight the substantial role of environmental factors, especially in regions with limited access to nutrition, healthcare, and psychosocial support. The influence of genetic factors appears to be modulated by the prevailing environmental context. Importantly, despite significant environmental challenges, heritability estimates remained relatively stable across regions, suggesting that environmental constraints may be uniformly limiting genetic expression in these settings. These results emphasize the need for a nuanced interpretation of heritability, particularly in diverse environmental contexts where phenotypic variance may remain similar across populations. Consequently, public health interventions should address broad structural and social determinants of growth while acknowledging the persistent role of genetic variation in childhood height. Such multifaceted approaches are essential for improving child growth and well‐being in resource‐constrained settings.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Study conception, design: B.B., R.D. Method and analysis: R.D., B.B. Drafting the manuscript: R.D., B.B. Interpretation, writing, and revision: R.D., B.B., S.H.L., E.H., S.B. Overall supervision: B.B. All authors contribute to the writing, review the results, and approve the final version of the manuscript.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

Table S4: Mean childhood (0‐5 years) height in the four geographic regions by age categories.
Table S5: Growth pattern of twin children stratified by geographical regions, age, and sex.
Table S6: Mean Child height of singletons by geographic area, age and sex.
Table S7: Same sex (SS) and different sex (DS) twin children height correlations by geographic regions.
Table S8a: One‐way ANOVA Bonferroni multiple comparison test for the mean height of children aged 0‐5 years.
Table S8b: One‐way ANOVA Bonferroni multiple comparison test for the mean height of children by geographic region and ages.
Table S9: Heritability estimates from mother‐child design by ages and geographic regions in children aged 0‐5 years.
Table S10: The estimated proportion of height variance due to genetic (h 2), shared (c 2) and unique (e 2) environmental variances across different ages in children age 0–5 years.
Figure S1: Sensitivity analysis of heritability with different proportion of MZ among SS twin pairs (p).

Figure S2: The trend of mean height of the twins across ages in four geographic regions, Asia, central and southwest Asia; LAC, Latin America and Caribbean; NAWAE, North Africa, west Asia and Europe; SSA, Sub‐Saharan Africa stratified by sex. The bars represent the mean child height, and the error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals.

Figure S3: The growth velocity (cm/year) across age and sex groups by region. Each horizontal bar represents the mean growth velocity for a specific age‐sex group, with error bars indicating 95% confidence intervals. Regions are color‐coded, allowing visual comparison of growth patterns across Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), sub‐Saharan Africa (SSA), and North Africa, West Asia, and Europe (NAWAE). Age‐sex groups are arranged on the y‐axis in ascending age order, with males listed before females at each age.
Figure S4: Height as a function of age by maternal education (top) and household wealth index quintiles (bottom).
Figure S5: The density plot of squared differences in height (cm2) (left). The squared differences in height have been represented as a function of age (months) (right).

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We sincerely thank the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) Program for providing access to the data. We also thank the University of South Australia for providing scholarship to R.D. and the National Health and Medical Research Council Leadership Award for providing funding to E.H. We are also grateful to Dr. Omar Karlsson for granting us access to their analysis code, and to A/Prof Benjamin W. Domingue for his valuable guidance and advice in data analysis. Open access publishing facilitated by University of South Australia, as part of the Wiley ‐ University of South Australia agreement via the Council of Australian University Librarians.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) Program (https://dhsprog). Restrictions apply to the availability of these data, which were used under license for this study. Data are available from the author(s) with the permission of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) Program (https://dhsprog). The data used in this study are obtained from the Demographic Health Surveys (DHS) available at (http://www.dhsprogram.com) and can be accessed by creating an account and submitting a brief research proposal (i.e., aims and analysis type). The analysis codes are available in the Data S2.
